Box 124, S.221 00 Lund (Sweden) Summary A model is described of catalyst-reactant interaction. It implies that one role of the catalyst is to supply energy into that vibrational mode of the reactant that most effectively takes the system to the activated state. In this way the dissipation of energy from the excited molecule is effectively counter- acted. By treating the system as the coupled, damped oscillator of classical mechanics, an expression is derived for the isocatalytic temperature (describ- ing the 'compensation effect') in terms of the vibrational frequencies of the reactant and the catalyst system. Examples are given of the application of this model to studies on heterogeneous as well as homogeneous systems. Introduction Homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis have many features in com- mon. One such feature is generally recognized, viz; the similarity between coordination and adsorption. The two processes are expected to affect the adsorbed/coordinated molecule in similar ways. This is clearly borne out, for example, by the similar trends in the molecular vibrations of metal carbonyls and of carbon monoxide adsorbed on metals [1]. An equally obvious dissimi- larity between the two classes of catalysis is the circumstance that in homogeneous catalysis the free coordination sites necessary for reaction are found on the same metal atom wheras in the heterogeneous case the free adsorption sites are usually found on neighbouring atoms. In this paper another similarity between homogeneous and heteroge- neous catalysis will be emphasized; the fact that in all cases (except some gas-phase reactions) the reaction proceeds in a condensed phase. More specifically, we will approach the problem of how the molecule can become activated in a condensed phase. It is well known that the processes of energy dissipation proceed rapidly in condensed phases [2]. One may then ask: how is it possible for a molecule to stay excited in order to react? The answer to such a question might be that in some cases this would be difficult if a catalyst was not present. The question is then transformed 0304-5102/89/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 71 into: what role has the catalyst? The present paper deals with a model on catalysis in an attempt to answer this question. The model to be described has been developed during the past few years by the present author [3-7] in relation to some earlier suggestions on resonance effects in catalysis [8,9]. It treats the catalyst as an energy reservoir ('heat bath') from which energy is supplied to the reacting system. More specifically, the model assumes that the catalyst is designed in such a way that it contains vibrators that have a vibrational frequency very closely equal to that of a vibration mode of the reactant molecule. On the other hand, this latter vibration mode must specifically be the one that corresponds to the way in which the molecule is deformed to reach the 'point of no return', i.e. the activated state. Example If the decomposition of nitrous oxide is considered, the reaction coordi- nate describing the reaction must be essentially the distance between the oxygen atom and its neighbouring nitrogen atom [7]. N=N 0 -N=N----0 > -N==N+0 The molecular vibration to be excited is then the N 0 stretching vibration. The argument is thus that a catalyst must be designed so that it can supply energy into this vibration mode at a rate that is greater than that with which the energy of excitation is lost by dissipation processes. If the frequency of the catalyst heat bath vibrator (or possibly its first overtone) is close to the frequency of the N 0 stretch, a state of resonance will enhance the rate of energy transfer and the conditions are good for a reaction to take place. The compensation effect In order to test an idea like that just mentioned, one must have quantitative data that can be used to verify or reject a proposition made from the hypothesis. In heterogeneous catalysis, such comparable, quantitative data are scarce, due to the large number of parameters that have to be controlled. One very interesting feature, however, that seems treatable is the so-called compensation effect [10]. It has been strongly pointed out by Linert [13] (see also other references in that paper) that this indication of a com- pensation effect is much more soundly based than the application of equation (2) for a series of similar catalysts. One can never be definitely sure that all the catalysts belong to one and the same group, with the same surface character- istics, etc. This has also been pointed out by Bond [14], who shows that one can obtain a set of parallel lines, giving the same but differing in reactivity per surface unit. In spite of these practical difficulties, the isocatalytic temperature is a quantity that is available and measurable to test the theory. Model In previous papers [5,15], the present author has used the analogy between the classical mechanics of a forced, damped harmonic oscillator system and the catalyst-reactant system. It may seem obsolete to use classi- cal models, but the starting point is the view that chemical reactions are first of all movements of atoms. Movements of atoms in a molecule have been quite successfully treated by various force field models to describe in- tramolecular vibrations and their energy relations [16,17]. These force field models are essentially classical physics. The application of quantum mechan- ics adds only smaller details to the results. Case studies from heterogeneous catalysis Let us now test these ideas on some cases where the compensation effect has been observed. One such system is the hydrodesulphurisation reaction, i.e. the breaking of the C S bonds in thiophene, for example, to form hydrogen sulphide via the interaction of hydrogen. The catalyst system for this reaction is usually molybdenum sulphide on an ALOa carrier, the effect of molybdenum is often found to be increased by the addition of smaller amounts of cobalt. This system has been dealt with from the point of view of the compensa- tion effect by Bond [14] basing his work on investigations by Mitchell and Scott [19]. The relevant data are reproduced in Fig. 5 from the discussion of Fig. 5. Reproduction from ref. 6 of the In A versus E plot as given by Mitchell and Scott [19] and Bond [14], respectively. The full line is from ref. 19 and the dashed lines are from ref. 14. 79 the present author [6] on these results. The slopes of the lines represent isocatalytic temperatures of 590 K, 633 K and 544 K, respectively. The point of importance now is to decide what internal vibration of the thiophene molecule will give the best condition for a C S bond to break. To the best of the author's understanding this must be precisely that ring bond stretching that has the highest character of C S bond stretch. This appears [20] at 834cm"1 and consequently from formula (22) one should expect an isocatalytic temperature = 596 K if perfect resonance was observed. If the frequencies of the heat bath are somewhat different, one should expect a higher value but still within an order of magnitude to that found experimen- tally. In the above-mentioned paper [6] some possible frequencies are indi- cated. For example, and only for the case of exemplification, the S H mode at 847 cm"1 [21] might be mentioned. Another striking example from heterogenous catalysis regarding the isocatalytic temperature is the dehydrogenation of formic acid, e.g. the work of Cremer [11] on oxide catalysts and of Boudart and Iglesia [22] on metal catalysts. One observes [23] for most of the systems isocatalytic temperatures that are in the range = 640 30 K. Case studies of homogeneous reactions Before discussing homogeneous catalysis in the context of the present model, it is necessary to point out that the formulae deduced for the energy transfer to a certain molecule must hold even if a catalyst is not present, as long as there is present some other suitable source of specific energy, a suitable heat bath. This heat bath is obviously of principal importance, and in many cases it may be constituted from a specific vibration of the solvent in which the reaction is taking place. The solvent cage around the dissolved species thus takes the place of the particle of a heterogeneous catalyst. This proposition has two corollaries: 1. Any reaction in a liquid phase might be characterized by a 'compensa- tion effect' provided a series of very nearly related reagents are compared. 2. For homogeneous catalytic reactions, the solvent may be of importance. This means that one should investigate carefully how the choice of solvent influences the reactivity of a catalytic system. 80 One such set of very nearly related reagents have been discussed by Linert [13], viz. a series of triphenylformazanes that isomerize in various fashions. In order to concentrate on essentials, we will treat only one reaction of those quoted by Linert [13] in the present paper. This reaction is depicted in Fig. 6. As Linert points out, this reaction most probably proceeds via an in-plane distortion of the phenyl group-diazo group angle. The experimental data that Linert quotes demonstrate beautifully an isocatalytic point of intersection of the Arrhenius lines. This figure is reproduced in Fig. 7. A heterogeneous analogue may be noted in this connection, i.e. the hydrogenation of ethyl cinnamate over a series of increasingly poisoned platinum catalysts, for which reaction a value of 0 = 340 K has been reported [29]. Final remarks The emphasis on the role of the solvent in the above examples should not obscure the possibility that a coordination catalyst can be built up that contains sufficient intrinsic vibration modes to activate a specific reaction. Examples of such complexes, rich in vibrational energy, might be the pen- tamethylcyclopentadienyl complexes that have quite different reactivity pat- terns from the non-substituted ones, or possibly the metallo-enzymes where the coordination centre has near access to vibrational energy stored in the protein structure. In this example we come, once more, close to heteroge- neous sytems of catalysis. The main argument of the present model is thus that a reaction is facilitated by a proper transfer of energy, selectively directed towards that vibration mode of the reactant where it is best needed. In the case of catalysis, the catalyst may act to supply the energy, to direct the energy in a proper manner and, in addition, to improve steric and other conditions for the outcome of the chemical reaction. coredata.dc:description: A model is described of catalyst-reactant interaction. It implies that one role of the catalyst is to supply energy into that vibrational mode of the reactant that most effectively takes the system to the activated state. In this way the dissipation of energy from the excited molecule is effectively counteracted. By treating the system as the coupled, damped oscillator of classical mechanics, an expression is derived for the isocatalytic temperature (describing the ‘compensation effect’) in terms of the vibrational frequencies of the reactant and the catalyst system. Examples are given of the application of this model to studies on heterogeneous as well as homogeneous systems.
coredata.dc:title: A model of selective energy transfer at the active site of the catalyst
